conclusion: Attempting to solve a problem about car headlights and light interaction with a paraboloid and hemispherical lens.
Understanding the setup: car headlights 92.8 cm above ground, paraboloid, hemispherical lens, light-blocking plate, light source at focal point F.
Focus on light entering lens perpendicular to vertical diameter MN, refractive index n = 4/3.
Goal is to find the length of the transparent part of light entering perpendicular to MN on the lens surface.
Recalling properties of paraboloids and light reflection.
Light emitted from focal point F and reflected off paraboloid travels parallel to the axis.
Paraboloid is likely a paraboloid of revolution.
Light-blocking plate likely blocks some reflected light.
Hemispherical lens placed with flat side perpendicular to paraboloid axis.
Light enters lens perpendicular to MN, which is horizontal.
Visualizing setup: paraboloid axis vertical, light source at F, light reflects parallel to axis.
Light enters flat side of lens horizontally.
Need to find chord on spherical surface where light enters.
Need radius R of hemispherical lens.
Considering relation of headlight height to lens radius.
Considering focal length relation to paraboloid base radius.
Light source at focal point, light emerges parallel to axis.
